importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report indicates the most recent update on the flooding situation, showing the ongoing impact and response efforts in Mexico as of this day.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding in five states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported 65 people still missing, with significant numbers in Veracruz, Hidalgo, Puebla, and Queretaro.
Veracruz recorded 29 deaths, Hidalgo 21, Puebla 13, and Queretaro 1.
Forty-three people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and four in Puebla.
Thousands of military troops have been deployed to assist across affected states, including the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard.
About 100,000 houses have been affected, with some near rivers having 'practically disappeared'.
Heavy rainfall was linked to remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rise and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall was recorded in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain, respectively.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply for about 263,000 affected users.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated there were no early meteorological signs indicating the extreme rainfall intensity, raising questions about Mexico’s alert system.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mexico has suffered a major flooding disaster with at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing, primarily in Veracruz, Hidalgo, and Puebla. The flooding, attributed to the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, brought extreme rainfall—up to 286mm in Puebla and 280mm in Veracruz—leading to river overflow, landslides, and widespread damage. Thousands of military personnel, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to deliver aid and restore services. Around 100,000 homes were affected, and nearly 263,000 people lost power, with repairs restoring over 80% of electricity. Officials, including President Claudia Sheinbaum and CNPC chief Laura Velazquez Alzua, have expressed concern about the lack of early meteorological warnings, raising questions about Mexico’s disaster preparedness systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
